children.text: Concept 1: Singing, alone and with others, music from various genres and diverse cultures.
PO 1. exhibiting singing and speaking voices.
PO 2. echoing spoken rhythmic patterns.
PO 3. singing music from memory.
PO 1. singing on pitch loud/soft, fast/slow, high/low.
PO 2. following a steady beat while singing.
PO 3. echo singing using syllable names.
PO 4. responding properly to basic conducting cues. (e.g., start/stop).
PO 1. singing an ostinato on pitch with an appropriate tone quality.
PO 2. performing a steady beat while singing
PO 3. singing using syllable names.
PO 4. responding properly to basic conducting cues. (e.g., start/stop).
PO. 1. singing rounds on pitch with an appropriate tone quality.
PO 2. singing rhythmic patterns with words.
PO 3. reading and singing using syllable names.
PO 4. responding properly to basic conducting cues. (e.g., start/stop).
PO 1. singing partner songs on pitch with an appropriate tone quality.
PO 2. singing unaccompanied with correct timing and intonation.
PO 3. reading and singing using pitch names.
PO 4. responding properly to formal conducting cues. (e.g., 3/4, 4/4).
PO 1 singing songs with descants on pitch with an appropriate tone quality, diction and posture.
PO 3. singing short songs from written notation.
PO 4. responding expressively to conducting cues (e.g., legato, dynamics).
PO 1. singing expressively on pitch with an appropriate tone quality, diction, posture, dynamics, phrasing, interpretation, and tempo.
PO 3. singing songs from written notation.
PO 4. responding expressively to conducting cues (e.g., legato, dynamics).
PO 1. singing with technical and stylistic accuracy (e.g., vocal production, posture).
PO2. singing music written in two parts.
PO 3. singing written notation using letters, numbers, and/or syllables.
PO 4. responding expressively to conducting cues (e.g., legato, dynamics).
PO 1. singing with technical and stylistic accuracy (e.g., vocal production, posture).
PO 2. singing music written in two parts.
PO3. singing written notation using letters, numbers, and/or syllables.
PO 4. responding expressively to conducting cues (e.g., legato, dynamics).
Concept 2: Playing instruments, alone and with others, music from various genres and diverse cultures.
PO 1. maintaining a steady beat.
PO 3. echoing rhythm patterns.
PO 1. maintaining a steady beat with a partner.
PO 2. playing sounds that are loud/soft, fast/slow, high/low.
PO 4. responding properly to basic conducting cues. (e.g., stop/start).
PO 1. maintaining a steady beat in a group.
PO 2. playing short melodic patterns that are loud/soft, fast/slow.
PO 3. playing with correct rhythmic duration quarter notes, eighth notes and quarter rests.
PO 4. responding properly to basic conducting cues. (e.g., stop/start).
PO 1 playing music from memory.
PO 2. playing a simple ostinato accompaniment using dynamics.
PO 3. playing with correct rhythmic duration half notes, whole notes and corresponding rests.
PO 4. responding properly to basic conducting cues. (e.g., stop/start).
PO 2. playing a short melody using appropriate dynamics.
PO 3. playing with correct rhythmic duration dotted half notes and dotted quarters.
PO 4. responding properly to formal conducting cues. (e.g., 3/4, 4/4).
PO 2. playing simple independent instrumental parts while other students sing or play contrasting parts.
PO 3. playing short songs from written notation.
PO 4. responding expressively to conducting cues (e.g., legato, dynamics).
PO 1. playing expressively with appropriate dynamics, phrasing, interpretation, articulation and tempo.
PO 2. playing by rote rhythmic patterns using sixteenth notes and syncopation in 2/4, 3/4, and 4/4 time signatures.
PO 4. playing with technical accuracy (e.g., posture, tone quality, breath control, mallet technique).
PO 1. playing expressively on the instruments of the genre and culture explored.
PO 4. playing with technical accuracy (e.g., posture, tone quality, breath control, mallet technique).
PO 1. playing expressively on the instruments of the genre and culture explored.
PO 4 playing with technical accuracy (e.g., posture, tone quality, breath control, mallet technique).
Concept 3: Improvising rhythms, melodies, variations, and accompaniments
PO 1 improvising an answer to a teacherperformed statement (to a steady beat)
PO 1. improvising an answer to a teacher performed statement (to a steady beat)
PO 1. improvising simple rhythmic accompaniments.
PO 1. improvising simple melodic phrases.
PO 1. singing and/or playing short improvised melodies for a specified time frame.
PO 1. improvising a melody based on a given tonality.
PO 1. playing an improvised accompaniment using tonic and dominant chords.
PO 1. improvising a harmonic accompanimen t using tonic, dominant, and subdominant chords.
PO 1. singing and/or playing short improvised melodies in a consistent style and meter.
Concept 4: Composing and arranging music.
PO 1. composing and notating short pieces using non-standard musical notation.
PO 1. creating music to accompany or tell a story.

PO 1. creating a short song within specified guidelines choosing from a variety of sound sources (e.g., body percussion, found objects, non-pitched instruments, pitched instruments, computer generated sound sources).

PO 1. creating short songs and/or instrumental pieces within specified guidelines choosing from a variety of sound sources (e.g., body percussion, found objects, non-pitched instruments, pitched instruments, computer generated sound sources).
PO 1. composing short pieces using standard musical notation in the treble clef within specified guidelines.
PO 1. composing and notating short pieces using standard musical notation in the treble clef within specified guidelines.
PO 1. creating/ arranging short songs and/or instrumental pieces in the treble clef within specified guidelines using technology.
PO 1. creating/ arranging short songs and/or instrumental pieces in the treble clef within specified guidelines using technology.
Concept 5: Reading and notating music.
PO 2. distinguishing melodic shape.
PO 4. recognizing non-standard musical notation
PO 1. recognizing melodic movement as up and down.
PO 2. Identifying quarter and eighth notes and quarter rests (e.g., Ta, Ti Ti).
PO 4. demonstrating melodic line and texture through nonstandard musical notation
PO 1. recognizing steps, skips and repeated notes in music.
PO 2. reading/ decoding quarter notes, eighth notes and quarter rests.
PO 4. reading and notating nonstandard musical notation.

PO 5. identifying parts/symbols in a musical score:
  • staves
  • clefs
PO 2. reading/ decoding half notes, whole notes and corresponding rests.
PO 3. identifying the letter names for the lines and spaces of the treble clef.
PO 4. reading and notating music using standard musical notation.

PO 5. identifying parts/symbols in a musical score:
  • dynamics
  • meter signatures
PO 2. reading/ decoding dotted half notes and dotted quarter notes.
PO 3. identifying the letter names for the lines and spaces of the treble clef.
PO 4. reading and notating music using standard musical notation.

PO 5. identifying parts/symbols in a musical score:
  • accidentals
  • phrasing marks
  • key signatures
PO 2. reading/ decoding sixteenth notes and sixteenth note patterns and simple syncopation in 2/4, 3/4 and 4/4 time signatures.
PO 3. identifying the letter names for the lines and spaces of the treble clef.
PO 4. reading and notating music using standard musical notation.
PO 5. defining terms and symbols used in music notation as identified in previous grade levels.
PO 2. conducting patterns and cues in duple and triple meter in time to the music.
PO 3. identifying the letter names for the lines and spaces of bass clef.
PO 4. reading and notating music using standard musical notation.
PO 5. defining terms and symbols used in music notation as identified in previous grade levels.
PO 2. identifying the intervals within a diatonic scale.
PO 3. identifying the letter names for the lines and spaces of bass clef.
PO 4. identifying major and minor scales.
PO 5. defining terms and symbols used in music notation as identified in previous grade levels.
PO 2. reading written notation using letters, numbers, and/or syllables.
PO 3. identifying the letter names for the lines and spaces of bass clef.
PO 4. identifying major and minor chords.
PO 5. defining terms and symbols used in music notation as identified in previous grade levels.
Concept 1: Understanding the relationships among music, the arts, and other disciplines outside the arts.
PO 1. exploring the relationship between music and dance by responding to sounds through movement.
PO 4. exploring and analyzing the relationship of music to language arts, visual arts, literature
PO 1. using body movement to show variations in rhythm, pitch or tempo.
PO 3. recognizing composers' motivations for creating music
PO 4. exploring and analyzing the relationship of music to language arts, visual arts, literature
Concept 2: Understanding music in relation to history and culture.
PO 1. discovering various uses of music in daily experiences (e.g., songs of celebration, seasons).
PO 1. recognizing various uses of music in daily experiences (e.g., game songs, marches, dance music, work songs).
PO 1. classifying various uses of music in daily experiences (e.g., songs of celebration, game songs, marches, T.V. and movie sound tracks, dance music, work songs).
PO 1. identifying music from various genres and diverse cultures.
PO 4. identifying different musical careers
PO 1. explaining the musical characteristics that make a piece appropriate for a specific event or function.
PO 2. applying appropriate movements to music from various cultures.
PO 3. identifying the origins and development of instruments
PO 4. describing different musical careers.
PO 1. describing the historical context and or influence of music on daily life, culture, politics, etc.
PO 2. describing the cultural context and or influence of music on daily life, culture, politics, etc.
PO 3. describing the origins and development of instruments
PO 4. classifying different musical careers.
PO 1. describing the characteristics that distinguish one style/period of music from another.
PO 2. comparing and contrasting the influences of music in various cultures.
PO 4. comparing and contrasting different musical careers.
PO 1. identifying the contributions of significant composers, performers and important pieces from major time periods and cultures, past and present.
PO 2. identifying the instrumentation of ensembles from various cultures.
PO 3. identifying the origins and development of written music
PO 4. analyzing the qualifications for different musical careers.
PO 1. comparing and contrasting the characteristics that distinguish one style/period of music from another various time periods
PO3. describing the origins and development of written music
PO 4. analyzing the qualifications for different musical careers.
Concept 3: Understanding music in relation to self and universal themes.
PO 1. describing what a piece of music makes them think of or about.
PO 2. describing why they like their favorite piece of music.
PO 1. identifying a song or other piece of music that is important to their family.
PO 2. explaining music preferences (I like it because…).
PO 1. drawing a picture that is inspired by listening to a specific piece of music.
PO 2. explaining music preferences (I like it because…).
PO 1. writing a story that is inspired by listening to a specific piece of music.
PO 2. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because…).
PO 1. describing the roles and impact music plays in their lives and the lives of others.
PO 2. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because…) from cultural judgments (It is important because…).
PO 1 reflecting on and discussing the roles and impact music plays in their lives and the lives of others.
PO 2. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because) from cultural judgments (It is important because…).
PO 1. explaining personal reactions to musical experiences, and identifying which musical aspects evoke these reactions.
PO 2. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because) from cultural judgments (It is important because…).
PO 1 describing the various ways that music conveys thought, emotion, and universal themes without the use of words.
PO 2. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because) from cultural judgments (It is important because…).
PO 1 describing the various ways that music conveys thought, emotion, and universal themes without the use of words.
PO 2. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because) from cultural judgments (It is important because…).
Concept 1: Listening to, analyzing, and describing music.
PO 1. identifying singing/ speaking voice.
PO 2. naming classroom instruments.
PO 3. identifying sounds as high and low.
PO 4. identifying music as fast or slow (tempo) and as loud or soft (dynamics), high or low (pitch).
PO 1. identifying melodic shape/pitch direction.
PO 2. identifying a variety of band, orchestra, and classroom instruments.
PO 3. recognizing patterns (e.g. rhythmic, melodic, dynamic, instrumental, tempo)
PO 4. demonstrating various moods heard in music through facial expression, body posture and/or movement.
PO 1. recognizing that music moves by steps, skips, leaps, and repeats.
PO 2. identifying the sound of a variety of band, orchestra, and classroom instruments.
PO 3. recognizing AB and ABA forms.
PO 4. responding to various moods heard in music through facial expression, body posture and/or movement.
PO 1. identifying steps, skips, leaps and repeats within a given piece of music.
PO 2. classifying instruments as band, orchestra or classroom.
PO 3. describing AB, ABA, and rounds.
PO 4. describing changes in mood while listening to music.
PO 1 describing the melodic movement within a given piece.
PO 3. describing canon and rondo forms.
PO 4 identifying musical examples by culture.
PO 1. classifying scales as major, minor.
PO 2. categorizing instruments as Western and non-Western.
PO 3. identifying AB, ABA, canon, and round forms when presented in performed and/or recorded music.
PO 4 identifying music examples by genre.
PO 1. classifying chords as major and minor.
PO 2. identifying instruments, Western and non-western, by family (e.g., woodwind, percussion, brass, strings, membranophones, idiophones).
PO 3. identifying contrasting meters and note/rest values.
PO 4. classifying musical examples by culture.
PO 1. comparing and contrasting simple music forms (e.g., AB, ABA, rondo, canon, round) when presented in performed and/or recorded music.
PO 3. analyzing musical elements in aural examples from diverse genres and cultures.
PO 4. classifying musical examples by genres.
PO 1. recognizing chord changes heard.
PO 1. recognizing chord changes heard.
PO 2. comparing and contrasting multiple interpretations (e.g., band, orchestra, vocal) of the same piece of music.
PO 3. identifying and analyzing the ways in which the elements of music are interrelated with elements of other arts.
PO 4. classifying and identifying musical examples by historical periods.
Concept 2: Evaluating music and music performances.
PO 1. expressing personal reactions to a music performance through drawings (I like it because…).
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. expressing personal reactions to a music performance through words or drawings (I like it because…).
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. expressing personal reactions to a music performance through words and drawings (I like it because…).
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. discussing/expla ining personal preferences for music (I like it because vs. it is good because…).
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because) from cultural judgments (It is important because…)
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. using established criteria (e.g., dynamics, pronunciation) to evaluate performances and compositions.
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. creating and applying established criteria to evaluate performances and compositions.
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. writing a critique of a performance, composition, improvisation, or arrangement based on established criteria.
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
PO 1. writing a critique of a performance, composition, improvisation, or arrangement based on established criteria.
PO 2. listening attentively while others perform and showing appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of the music performed.
Strand 1: Create
Concept 1: Singing, alone and with others, music from various genres and diverse cultures.
Beginning
PO 101. singing their own instrumental parts within an ensemble.
PO 102. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamics.
PO 103. singing rhythmic patterns of different meters.
PO 104. singing their own instrumental parts with good posture and with proper breath support.
Intermediate
PO 201. singing their own instrumental parts within an ensemble.
PO 202. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamics.
PO 203. singing rhythmic patterns of different meters.
PO 204. singing their own instrumental parts with good posture and with proper breath support.
Advanced
PO 301. singing their own instrumental parts within an ensemble.
PO 302. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamics.
PO 303. singing rhythmic patterns of different meters.
PO 304. singing their own instrumental parts with good posture and with proper breath support.
Concept 2: Playing instruments, alone and with others, music from various genres and diverse cultures.
Beginning
PO 101. properly assembling and identifying the various parts of their instruments.
PO 102. demonstrating proper care and maintenance of their instrument.
PO 103. playing solo and ensemble literature on grade level 1-2 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 104. identifying and playing individually and with others the following note and rest values while maintaining a steady beat: whole, half, quarter, eighth, dotted half, dotted quarter.
PO 105. playing the Concert Bb, F, and Eb major scales one octave on wind and mallet percussion instruments.
PO 106. identifying and playing articulations and symbols as they occur in the repertoire.
PO 107. demonstrating the basic embouchure, posture, and hand/stick/mallet position appropriate for characteristic tone production on their instrument.
PO 108. playing, on pitch, in rhythm, with appropriate articulation, dynamics, and tempo.
PO 109. playing exercises from memory at appropriate level.
PO 110. playing notated music at grade level 1- 2 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 111. playing repertoire accurately and with good breath control, tone quality, and technique at grade level 1-2 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 112. sight-reading repertoire accurately and expressively at one level below performance level.
PO 113. playing a varied repertoire from different genres at appropriate level (e.g., traditional, military, popular, folk).
PO 114. responding to basic conductor's cues (e.g., tempo and dynamics).
PO 115. playing independent parts while others play contrasting parts within an ensemble at grade level 1-2 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 116. playing together as an ensemble (e.g. tempo and balance).
PO 117. playing by rote short rhythmic and/or melodic patterns, and/or intervallic while maintaining a steady beat.
PO 118. moving in a synchronized manner with music (e.g., hand clapping, foot tapping, marching).
PO 119. additionally for percussionists: playing the appropriate percussion rudiments (e.g., long, 5-stroke, 7-stroke rolls, paradiddles, flams).
PO 120. recognizing when their instruments are in tune by listening to a given pitch.
Intermediate
PO 201 properly assembling and identifying the various parts of their instruments.
PO 202 demonstrating proper care and maintenance of their instrument.
PO 203. playing solo and ensemble literature on grade level 2-3 on a scale of 1-6 .

PO 204. identifying and playing individually and with others the following note and rest values while maintaining a steady beat: whole, half, quarter, eighth, dotted half, dotted quarter and sixteenth as well as other note and rest values encountered in the repertoire.
PO 205. playing Ab, C, G and D major scales for one octave and a chromatic scale in the appropriate range.
PO 206. identifying and playing articulations and symbols as they occur in the repertoire.

PO 207. demonstrating how factors such as embouchure shape and tension, mouthpiece and reed selection, slide position, stick/mallet placement, and fingerings influences the intonation and tone quality and their instrument.
PO 208. playing, on pitch, in rhythm, with appropriate articulation, dynamics, phrasing, and tempo.
PO 209. playing exercises from memory at appropriate level.
PO 210. playing notated music at grade level 2- 3 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 211. playing repertoire accurately and with good breath control, tone quality, and technique at grade level 2-3 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 212. sight-reading repertoire accurately and expressively at one level below performance level.
PO 213. playing a varied repertoire from different genres at appropriate level (e.g., traditional, military, popular, folk).
PO 214. responding to conductor's cues (e.g., phrasing and expression).
PO 215. playing independent parts while others play contrasting parts within an ensemble at grade level 2-3 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 216. playing together as an ensemble (e.g., tempo, intonation, balance, and blend).
PO 217. playing by rote short rhythmic and/or melodic patterns in tempo.
PO 218. moving in a synchronized manner with music (e.g., hand clapping, foot tapping, marching).
PO 219. additionally for percussionists: applying percussion rudiments appropriate to the repertoire encountered.
PO 220. tuning their own instrument using a tuner or other pitch reference.
PO 221. recognizing intonation within the ensemble.
Advanced
PO 301 properly assembling and identifying the various parts of their instruments.
PO 302 demonstrating proper care and maintenance of their instrument.
PO 303. playing solo and ensemble literature on grade level 3-5 on a scale of 1-6.

PO 304. identifying and playing individually and with others the following note and rest values while maintaining a steady beat: whole, half, quarter, eighth, dotted half, dotted quarter and sixteenth as well as other note and rest values encountered in the repertoire.
PO 305. playing scale structures appropriate to the repertoire encountered for full practical range.
PO 306. identifying and playing articulations and symbols as they occur in the repertoire.

PO 307. demonstrating how factors such as embouchure shape and tension, mouthpiece and reed selection, slide position, stick/mallet placement, and fingerings influences the intonation and tone quality and their instrument.
PO 308. playing expressively, on pitch, in rhythm, with appropriate articulation, dynamics, phrasing, and tempo.
PO 309. playing exercises/music from memory at appropriate level.
PO 310. playing notated music grade level 3-5 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 311. playing repertoire accurately and with good breath control, tone quality, and technique at grade level 3-5 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 312. sight-reading repertoire accurately and expressively at one level below performance level.
PO 313. playing varied literature from different genres at appropriate level from the standard repertoire.
PO 314. responding to conductor's cues (e.g., style, expression, part cueing).
PO 315. playing independent parts while others play contrasting parts within an ensemble at grade level 3-5 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 316. performing together as an ensemble (e.g., tempo, intonation, balance, blend, and expression).
PO 317. playing by rote medium-length rhythmic and/or melodic patterns in tempo.
PO 318. moving in a synchronized manner with music (e.g., hand clapping, foot tapping, marching).
PO 319. additionally for percussionists: applying percussion rudiments appropriate to the repertoire encountered.
PO 320. adjusting appropriately to inherent intonation tendencies of their own instrument.
PO 321. recognizing intonation within the ensemble and responding appropriately.
Distinction
PO 403. playing solo and ensemble literature on grade level 5-6 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 404. identifying and playing individually and with others all note and rest values as encountered in the repertoire.
PO 405. playing all major/minor and selected modal scale structures, throughout the practical range of the instrument.
PO 408. playing expressively, on pitch, in rhythm, with appropriate articulation, dynamics, phrasing, finesse, and tempo.
PO 409. performing solo literature from memory at the appropriate level.
PO 410. playing notated music grade level 5-6 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 411. playing repertoire accurately and with good breath control, tone quality, and technique at grade level 5-6 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 412. transposing repertoire at sight accurately and expressively (e.g., reading different clefs, trumpet in D played on Bb instrument).
PO 413. playing varied literature from different genres at appropriate level from within and outside the standard repertoire (e.g., international, transcriptions, new works).
PO 414. conduct an ensemble with appropriate gestures, tempo, expression, and cueing.
PO 415. playing independent parts while others play contrasting parts within an ensemble at grade level 5-6 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 416. consistently performing together as an ensemble (e.g., tempo, intonation, balance, blend, expression, and sensitivity).
PO 417. playing music by rote in tempo with appropriate expression.
PO 420. adjusting appropriately to inherent intonation and timbre tendencies of their own instrument.
PO 421. adjusting intonation to pitch tendencies within the ensemble and tonal context.
Concept 3: Improvising rhythms, melodies, variations, and accompaniments.
Beginning
PO 101. playing improvised melodies for a minimum of 4 measures within teacher specified guidelines (e.g., using a limited pitch set).
PO 102. playing improvised melodic and rhythmic accompaniments for a minimum of 4 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
Intermediate
PO 201. playing simple improvised melodies within an appropriate harmonic structure for a minimum of 8 measures over an accompaniment within teacher specified guidelines.
PO 202. playing melodic and rhythmic improvised accompaniments for a minimum of 8 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
Advanced
PO 301. playing complex improvised melodies within an appropriate harmonic structure, with expression, for a minimum of 12 measures over chord progression.
PO 302. playing melodic and rhythmic improvised accompaniments a minimum of 12 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
Distinction
PO 401. playing complex improvised melodies within an appropriate harmonic structure, with expression, for a minimum of 24 measures over chord progression.
PO 402. playing melodic and rhythmic improvised accompaniments a minimum of 24 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
Concept 4: Composing and arranging music
Beginning
PO 101. identifying how changing compositional elements of music (e.g., dynamics, tone color, tempo) can change the style and experience of the music.
PO 102. creating short compositions for their own instrument, a minimum of 2 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
Intermediate
PO 201. manipulating compositional elements of music (e.g., dynamics, tone color, tempo) to change the style and experience of the music.
PO 202. creating short compositions for their own instrument or others, a minimum of 4 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
PO 203. transposing/arranging/transcribing music within teacher specified guidelines.
Advanced
PO 301. analyzing the compositional and stylistic elements that differentiate various musical genres.
PO 302. creating short compositions for duet or small ensemble, a minimum of 8 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
PO 303. transposing/arranging/transcribing music within teacher specified guidelines.
Distinction
PO 402. composing a musical work for small or large ensemble, or solo with accompaniment.
PO 403. arranging or transcribing a musical work for small or large ensemble, or solo with accompaniment.
Concept 5: Reading and notating music.
Beginning
PO101. identifying the key of their instrument in relation to concert pitch.
PO 102. explaining the function of the following time signatures: 4/4, 3/4, 2/4, 6/8, cut time.
PO 103. explaining and applying the terms encountered in the repertoire.
PO 104. playing expressively, on pitch and in rhythm, dynamics, phrasing, tempo markings encountered in the repertoire.
PO 105. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music encountered in the repertoire.
PO 106. identifying steps, skips, and repeated notes encountered in the repertoire.
PO 107. explaining the function of the key signatures and accidentals.
PO 108. describing and playing simple musical forms as encountered in repertoire.
Intermediate
PO 201. identifying the key of other instruments within the ensemble in relation to concert pitch.
PO 202. explaining the difference between simple/compound and duple/triple.
PO 203. explaining and applying the terms encountered in the repertoire.
PO 204. playing expressively, on pitch and in rhythm, dynamics, phrasing, tempo markings encountered in the repertoire.
PO 205. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music encountered in the repertoire.
PO 206. identifying intervals encountered in the repertoire.
PO 207. recognizing and playing key signatures and accidentals in the repertoire.
PO 208. describing and playing musical forms as encountered in repertoire.
Advanced
PO 302. explaining various asymmetrical meters.
PO 303. explaining and applying the terms encountered in the repertoire.
PO 304. playing expressively, on pitch and in rhythm, dynamics, phrasing, tempo markings encountered in the repertoire.
PO 305. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music encountered in the repertoire.
PO 306. identifying intervals encountered in the repertoire.
PO 307. recognizing and playing key signatures and accidentals in the repertoire.
PO 308. describing and playing musical forms as encountered in the repertoire.
Distinction
PO 408. synthesizing characteristics of musical structure and form into performance practice.
Strand 1: Create
Concept 1: Singing, alone and with others, music from different genres and diverse cultures.
Beginning
PO 101. singing their own instrumental parts within an ensemble.
PO 102. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamic.
PO 103. singing rhythmic patterns of different meters.
PO 104. singing their own instrumental parts with good posture and with proper breath support.
Intermediate
PO 201. singing their own instrumental parts within an ensemble.
PO 202. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamics.
PO 202. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamics.
PO 204. singing their own instrumental parts with good posture and with proper breath support.
Advanced
PO 301. singing their own instrumental parts within an ensemble.
PO 302. singing their own instrumental parts in tune with appropriate articulation, phrasing and dynamics.
PO 303. singing rhythmic patterns of different meters.

Distinction

Concept 2: Playing instruments, alone and with others, music from different genres and diverse cultures.
Beginning
PO 101. identifying the various parts of their instrument.
PO 102. exhibiting proper care and maintenance of their instrument
PO 103. maintaining good posture and playing position.
PO 104. utilizing the proper left and right hand holding posture for their stringed instrument.

PO 105. exhibiting proper bow control, including the techniques used for staccato, slurred staccato, detache, slurs, double stops using one finger down, down bow, up bow, open strings, bow lift, pizzicato.
PO 106. playing D, G, A, C, and F major one octave scales, arpeggios, and triads using proper half step fingering.
PO 107. recognizing when their instruments are in tune by listening to a given pitch.
PO108. aurally distinguishing and performing on their instrument half and whole steps.
PO 110. producing a characteristic tone quality on their instrument.
PO 111. playing by rote short rhythmic, melodic, and/or intervallic patterns (one octave) while maintaining a steady beat.
PO 112. performing solo or ensemble pieces at grade level 1-2 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 113. sight reading simple rhythmic and melodic exercises one level below performance level.
PO 114. responding to a variety of conducting cues (e.g., entrance cue, simple duple/ triple patterns, cutoffs).
PO 115. playing simple music from a variety of genres, cultures, and styles.
PO 116. transposing a simple melody (e.g., dore- mi on different strings).
Intermediate
PO 201. identifying the various parts and names of other instruments in their ensemble.
PO 202. exhibiting proper care and maintenance of their instrument
PO 203. maintaining good posture and playing position
PO 204. utilizing the proper left and right hand holding posture while shifting for their stringed instrument.
PO 205. exhibiting proper bow control and technique using spiccato, changing strings with wrist action, col legno, ricochet, and double stops.

PO 206. performing two octave scales, triads and arpeggios in the keys of D, G, A, C and F major, one octave scales, triads, and arpeggios in additional major keys (playing in at least one position higher than first with technical facility), and playing one octave scales, triads and arpeggios in the keys of d, g, b, a, and e minor.
PO 207. tuning their own instrument using a tuner or other pitch reference.
PO 208. recognizing pitch discrepancies and responding appropriately in a unison context.
PO 209. playing a natural harmonic on each string.
PO 210. incorporating rudimentary aspects of vibrato into their playing.
PO 211. playing by rote rhythmic, melodic and/or intervallic patterns (two octaves) while maintaining a steady beat.
PO 212. performing solo or ensemble pieces at grade level 2-3 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 213. sight reading rhythmic and melodic exercises and/or music one level below performance level.
PO 214. responding to a variety of conducting cues (e.g., crescendo, decrescendo, legato).
PO 215. playing and performing music from a wide variety of genres, cultures, and styles.
PO 216. playing simple melodies in at least two keys.
Advanced
PO 301. explaining how adjustments made to various parts of an instrument affect the sound production of that instrument (e.g., relationship of bridge, sound post, fingerboard, and bow).
PO 302. exhibiting proper care and maintenance of their instrument
PO 303. maintaining good posture and playing position
PO 304. utilizing the proper left and right hand holding posture for their stringed instrument (e.g., shifting, extensions).

PO 305. exhibiting proper bow control and technique using accented détaché, legato détaché, martelé, spiccato, string crossings at varying tempi, and bow articulation using variations of slurred and détaché groupings of notes.
PO 306. playing two or three octave (where possible) major and minor scales up to four sharps and four flats plus the g melodic minor using variations in bowing articulation.
PO 307. tuning their own instrument using a pitch reference.
PO 308. recognizing pitch discrepancies and responding appropriately in an harmonic context.
PO 309. playing natural harmonics of an octave, octave and a fifth, and two octaves on all open strings and fingered harmonics in first position.
PO 310. performing vibrato (with any of the four fingers), using appropriate bow length and weight for flautando, ponticello in various tempi.
PO 311. playing by rote rhythmic, melodic and/or intervallic patterns in major and minor key signatures up to four sharps and four flats.
PO 312. performing solo or ensemble pieces at grade level 3-5 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 313. sight reading music comparable to one level below performance level.
PO 314. responding to various patterns and cues representing meters in one, two, three, four, five or six beat patterns, constant or changing tempi, and mood or style indicators.
PO 315. playing, performing, and/or auditioning using music from a wide variety of genres, cultures, and styles.
PO 316. playing simple melodies in several keys.
Distinction
PO 406. playing all major and minor scales in two or three octave (where possible) plus the g melodic minor using variations in bowing articulation.
PO 412. performing solo or ensemble pieces at grade level 6 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 416. playing complex melodies in several keys.
Concept 3: Improvising rhythms, melodies, variations, and accompaniments.
Beginning
PO 101. improvising simple melodic figures or phrases within teacher specified guidelines.
Intermediate
PO 201. improvising simple melodic lines utilizing whole, half, and quarter notes/rests in a beginning level key.
Advanced
PO 301. improvising simple melodic phrases and simple accompaniment patterns over a simple chord progression (e.g., tonic-dominant, 12 bar blues).
Concept 4: Composing and arranging music
Beginning
PO 101. composing simple melodic motives or phrases within teacher specified guidelines.
Intermediate
PO 201. composing rhythmic and melodic exercises within teacher specified guidelines.
Advanced
PO 301. creating short compositions for duet or small ensemble, a minimum of 8 measures within teacher specified guidelines.
Distinction
PO 401. composing a musical work for small or large ensemble, or solo with accompaniment.
Concept 5: Reading and notating music.
Beginning
PO 101. reading music in simple meters (e.g., 4/4, 3/4, 2/4, 6/8, cut time).
PO 102. identifying and applying musical terms and symbols appropriate to the repertoire encountered.
PO 103. playing expressively on pitch and in rhythm, dynamics, phrasing, and tempo markings encountered in the repertoire. (e.g., staccato, marcato, legato, ritardando, accent and fermata).
PO 104. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music encountered in the repertoire.
PO 105. explaining the function of the key signature, time signature, and accidentals.
PO 106. describing and playing simple musical forms as encountered in the repertoire.
Intermediate
PO 201. reading and notating music in simple and compound meters (e.g., 6/8, 9/8, cut time).
PO 202. identifying and applying musical terms and symbols appropriate to the repertoire encountered.
PO 203. playing expressively on pitch and in rhythm, dynamics, phrasing, tempo markings encountered in the repertoire (e.g., tenuto and harmonic markings).
PO 204. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music encountered in the repertoire.
PO 205. applying key signatures, time signatures, and accidentals to repertoire.
PO 206. describing and playing musical forms as encountered in the repertoire.
Advanced
PO 301. reading and notating music in various meters (e.g., 6/4, 3/8, 2/2).
PO 302. identifying and applying musical terms and symbols appropriate to the repertoire encountered.
PO 303. playing expressively on pitch and in rhythm, dynamics, phrasing, tempo markings encountered in the repertoire.
PO 304. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music encountered in the repertoire.
PO 305. applying key signatures, time signatures, and accidentals to repertoire.
PO 305. applying key signatures, time signatures, and accidentals to repertoire.
PO 305. applying key signatures, time signatures, and accidentals to repertoire.
Distinction
PO 406. synthesizing characteristics of musical structure and form into performance practice.
Strand 1: Create
Concept 1: Singing, alone and with others, music from various genres and diverse cultures.
Beginning
PO 101. maintaining a steady beat with auditory assistance (e.g., metronome, clapping, tapping feet, instruments).
PO 102. adjusting and matching pitches.
PO 103. singing with proper posture with frequent prompting.
PO 104. recognizing breathy, glottal, and coordinated onsets and releases and developing ability to use coordinated onsets and release with frequent prompting.
PO 105. using the articulators to produce clarity of consonants and purity of vowels with frequent prompting.
PO 106. developing an awareness of singer's resonance by describing the sensations that occur to produce a clear and free tone with frequent prompting.
PO 107. recognizing and using chest, head, and/or falsetto registrations appropriately with frequent prompting.

PO 108. singing a vocal part while maintaining a balance of volume and blend of vocal quality with other members of the same section utilizing level 1-3 choral literature in a standard choral formation.

PO 109. singing a variety of choral music representing various genres (e.g., classical, spirituals, folk songs, jazz, mariachi, African) in unison and two parts at a difficulty level of 1-3 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 110. singing a variety of music literature with appropriate, dynamics, timbre, tempi, phrasing, articulation balance, and blend with frequent assistance from teacher.
PO 111. responding to basic conducting gestures.
PO 112. singing music in 1-3 different languages with correct pronunciation.
PO 113. singing a cappella in rehearsal settings (e.g., warm ups, rounds).
PO 114. singing and performing level 1-3 literature from memory.
PO 115. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of vocal technique (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Intermediate
PO 201. maintaining a steady beat with visual assistance (e.g., conductor's cues).
PO 202. adjusting and matching pitches and developing an awareness of tuning to self and other voices or instruments.
PO 203. singing with proper posture with occasional prompting.
PO 204. using breathy, glottal, and coordinated onsets and releases and developing ability to use coordinated onsets and release with occasional prompting.
PO 205. using the articulators to produce clarity of consonants and purity of vowels with occasional prompting.
PO 206. singing with a resonant, clear and free tone with occasional prompting.
PO 207. recognizing and using chest, head, and/or falsetto registrations appropriately with occasional prompting.

PO 208. singing a vocal part while maintaining a balance of volume and blend of vocal quality with at least one member of the same section utilizing level 2-4 choral literature in beginning mixed formations.

PO 209. singing a variety of choral music representing various genres (e.g., classical, spirituals, folk songs, jazz, mariachi, African) in at least three parts at a difficulty level of 2-4 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 210. singing a variety of music literature with appropriate dynamics, timbre, tempi, phrasing, articulation, balance, and blend with occasional assistance from the teacher.
PO 211. responding to deviation in conducting patterns for stylistic interpretation.
PO 212. singing music in 2-4 different languages with correct pronunciation.
PO 213. singing a cappella music in rehearsal settings. singing music with a capella sections in rehearsal and performance settings.
PO 214. singing and performing level 3-4 literature from memory
PO 215. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of vocal technique (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Advanced
PO 301. maintaining a steady beat without external assistance.
PO 302. adjusting and matching pitches and demonstrating a consistent ability to tune to self and other voices or instruments.
PO 303. singing with proper posture with minimal prompting.
PO 304. using breathy, glottal, and coordinated onsets and releases and developing ability to use coordinated onsets and release with minimal prompting.
PO 305. using the articulators to produce clarity of consonants and purity of vowels with minimal prompting.
PO 306. singing with a resonant, clear and free tone with minimal prompting.
PO 307. using chest, head, and/or falsetto registrations appropriately with minimal prompting.

PO 308. singing a vocal part while maintaining a balance of volume and blend of vocal quality with other members of the ensemble using level 3-5 choral literature in choral formations requiring processions, recessions, and/or choreography, and more complex mixed formations.

PO 309. singing a variety of choral music representing various genres (e.g., classical, spirituals, folk songs, jazz, mariachi, African) in at least four parts at a difficulty level of 3-5 on a scale of 1-6.
PO 310. singing a variety of music literature with appropriate dynamics, timbre, tempi, phrasing, articulation, balance, and blend with minimal assistance from the teacher.
PO 311. responding to various conducting gestures and patterns including changing and mixed meters.
PO 312. singing music in 3-5 different languages with correct pronunciation.
PO 313. singing a cappella music in a performance setting.
PO 314. singing and performing level 3-5 literature from memory.
PO 315. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of vocal technique (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Distinction
PO 401. maintaining a steady beat, recognizing the macro and micro beat, exhibiting an understanding through appropriate movement (e.g., conducting, choreography).
PO 402. tuning more complex chords (e.g. thicker, dissonant, jazz chords) with an understanding of the importance of their pitch within the chord structure.
PO 403. assuming correct singing posture with no teacher prompting.
PO 404. using correct form of onset for style of music with no teacher prompting.
PO 405. using the articulators to produce clarity of consonants and purity of vowels with no teacher prompting.
PO 406. singing with a resonant, clear and free tone with no prompting.
PO 407. using chest, head and/or falsetto registrations appropriately with no teacher prompting.

PO 408 singing and holding vocal parts by themselves while maintaining a balance of volume and blend of vocal quality with other members of the ensemble using advanced mixed arrangements or more complex movement, choreography.
PO 409 singing a variety of choral music representing various genres (e.g., classical, spirituals, folk songs, jazz, mariachi, African) in 4-8 parts at a difficulty level of 4-6 or collegiate level.
PO 410. singing a variety of music literature with appropriate , balance, and blend by correctly reading and interpreting printed scores and applying stylistic knowledge.
PO 411. conducting an ensemble on beginning level literature.
PO 412. singing music in 5 or more different languages with correct pronunciation.
PO 413. Singing a cappella music in mixed formations (as opposed to standard SATB sections) or with one person to a part.
PO 414. singing and performing advanced level literature from memory with a shorter rehearsal span and/or performing extended works (e.g., Messiah).
PO 415 using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of vocal technique (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Concept 2: Playing instruments, alone and with others, music from various genres and diverse cultures.
Beginning
PO 101. adding simple instrumental accompaniments (e.g. hand percussion instruments or solo instrument) singing, using choir members when feasible.
Intermediate
PO 201. adding moderate instrumental accompaniments (e.g. small combo or chamber ensemble) to singing, using choir members when feasible.
Advanced
PO 301. adding complex instrumental accompaniment (e.g. jazz band, wind ensemble, orchestra, percussion ensemble, mariachi ensemble, etc.) to singing, using choir members when feasible.
Distinction

PO 401. adding complex instrumental accompaniment (e.g., jazz band, wind ensemble, orchestra, percussion ensemble, mariachi ensemble) to singing, using choir members, student musicians or professional musicians.
Concept 3: Improvising rhythms, melodies, variations, and accompaniments.
Beginning
PO 101. using appropriate improvisation techniques when required by the literature (e.g., jazz, gospel, aleatoric, blues). [see Strand 1, Concept
Intermediate
PO 201. using appropriate improvisation techniques when required by the literature (e.g., jazz, gospel, aleatoric, blues).
Advanced
PO 301. using appropriate improvisation techniques when required by the literature (e.g., jazz, gospel, aleatoric, blues).
Distinction
PO 401. using advanced solo improvisation techniques when required by the literature (e.g., jazz gospel, aleatoric, blues).
Concept 4: Composing and arranging music
Beginning
PO 101. composing a variation of a theme by replacing or changing some of the note values and/or pitches.
PO 102. describing how the changing elements of music (e.g., dynamics, tone color, tempo) can effect the style of the music.
PO 103. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of composing and arranging music (e.g. sequencing software, composing software, etc.).
Intermediate
PO 201. creating short compositions with a minimum of 4 measures within teacher specified guidelines using standard notation.
PO 202. changing musical elements within a given song to demonstrate how the compositional choices effect the song.
PO 203 using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of composing and arranging music (e.g. sequencing software, composing software, etc.).
Advanced
PO 301. creating short compositions with a minimum of 8 measures within teacher specified guidelines using standard notation.
PO 302. arranging short sections of a song within teacher specified guidelines using standard notation and a variety of musical elements.
PO 303 using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of composing and arranging music (e.g. sequencing software, composing software, etc.).
Distinction
PO 401. creating complete compositions a minimum of 16 measures in length using teacher specified guidelines.
PO 402. creating complete compositions a minimum of 16measures in length using student chosen guidelines and any notional system.
PO 403 using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of composing and arranging music (e.g. sequencing software, composing software, etc.).
Concept 5: Reading and notating music.
Beginning
PO 101. reading, performing, identifying and notating whole, half, dotted half, quarter and eighth notes and rests in simple meters.
PO 102. reading, singing, identifying, and/or notating a series of pitches within a major scale utilizing mostly stepwise motion and beginning work on intervals of 3rds, 5ths and octaves.
PO103. identifying and utilizing basic scoresymbols (e.g., fermata, repeat signs and double bar lines, note names) in 1 or 2 part literature.
PO 104. singing major scales and identifying whole and half step patterns.
PO 105. sight-singing melodies with stepwise motion and intervals of 3rds, 5ths, and octaves utilizing a methodology (such as solfège or numbers).
PO 106 sight-singing examples or literature in unison or two-part homophonic texture.
PO 107. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of reading and notating music (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Intermediate
PO 201. reading, performing, identifying and notating whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth, and dotted notes and rests in simple and complex meters.
PO 202. . reading, singing, identifying, and/or notating a series of pitches within major and minor scales continuing work on 3rd, 5ths and octaves, and adding the intervals of 4ths and 6ths.
PO 203. identifying and utilizing common score symbols in at least 3 part literature.
PO 204. singing major and minor scales and identifying whole and half step patterns.
PO 205. sight-singing melodies with disjunct motion adding the intervals of 4ths and 6ths utilizing a methodology (such as solfège or numbers).
PO 206. sight-singing examples or literature in 2-3 part homophonic and simple polyphonic texture.
PO 207. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of reading and notating music (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Advanced
PO 301. reading, performing, identifying and notating whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth, and dotted notes and rests in complex and changing meters.
PO 302. reading, singing, identifying, and/or notating a series of pitches within major and minor scales utilizing all intervals.
PO 303. identifying and utilizing all score symbols in at least 4 part literature.
PO 304. singing major, minor, chromatic, whole tone scales and identifying whole and half step patterns.
PO 305. sight-singing melodies with disjunct motion adding the intervals of 7ths and intervals larger than an octave utilizing a methodology (such as solfège or numbers).
PO 306. sight-singing examples or literature in 4-6 part homophonic and polyphonic texture.
PO 307. using technology and multimedia to enhance knowledge and application of reading and notating music (e.g., recordings, instructional DVDs, computer applications).
Distinction
PO 401. reading performing, identifying and notating whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth, and dotted notes and rests in complex and changing meters at faster tempos.
PO 402. reading singing, identifying and/or notating a series of pitches within major and minor and modes utilizing all intervals.
PO 403. identifying and utilizing all score symbols in 6to 8 part literature.
PO 404. singing major, minor, chromatic, whole tone scales and modes and identifying whole and half step patterns.
PO 405. sight-singing melodies with greater rhythmic and textural complexity utilizing a methodology (such as solfège or numbers).
PO 406. sight singing examples or literature in 5-8 part complex homophonic and polyphonic texture.
PO 407. using technology to create multi-media projects on selected music topics (e.g. using Finale, Sibelius – music notation software).
Strand 2: Relate
Concept 1: Understanding the relationships among music, the arts, and other disciplines outside the arts.
Beginning
PO 101. recognizing the relationship between music and various functions/events (e.g., specific to content area).
PO 103. recognizing composers' motivations for creating the music being performed by the students.
PO 104. recognizing and applying the relationship between rhythm and mathematics as it occurs in the repertoire.
PO 105. recognizing the connections between music and other content areas as encountered in the repertoire.
PO 106. exploring the connections between choral text and language arts and social studies (choral only).
PO 107. describing and applying the physical factors essential to playing/singing within the repertoire (e.g., posture, breathing, fingerings, bowings).
PO 108. analyzing and applying the effect the voice/instrument's physical properties has on its sound as student skill level increases.
Intermediate
PO 201. explaining the relationship between music and various functions/ events (e.g., specific to content area).
PO 202. identifying how music can be transcribed from one music medium to another (e.g., one instrument to another, one ensemble to another).
PO. 203 recognizing composers' motivations for creating the music being performed by the students.
PO 204. explaining and applying the relationship between rhythm and mathematics as it occurs in the repertoire.
PO 205. recognizing the connections between music and other content areas as encountered in the repertoire.
PO 206 exploring the connections between choral text and language arts and social studies (choral only).
PO 207. describing and applying the physical factors essential to playing/singing within the repertoire (e.g., posture, breathing, fingerings, bowings).
PO 208. analyzing and applying the effect the voice/instrument's physical properties has on its sound as student skill level increases.
PO 209. recognizing acoustic properties as they effect the performers and the performance space.

PO 210. comparing how the basic elements of two or more arts disciplines can be used to express similar events, emotions, scenes, or ideas (e.g., sound in music, movement in dance, images in art, words in poetry).
Advanced
PO 301. analyzing the relationship between music and various functions/ events (e.g., specific to content area).
PO 302. Explaining how music can be transcribed from one medium to another (e.g., one instrument to another one ensemble to another).
PO 303. recognizing composers' motivations for creating the music being performed for the students.
PO 304. analyzing and applying the relationship between rhythm and mathematics as it occurs in the repertoire.
PO 305. recognizing the connections between music and other content areas as encountered in the repertoire.
PO 306. exploring the connections between choral text and language arts and social studies (choral only).
PO 307. describing and applying the physical factors essential to playing/singing within the repertoire (e.g., posture, breathing, fingerings, bowings).
PO 308. analyzing and applying the effect the voice/instrument's physical properties has on its sound as student skill level increases.
PO 309. adjusting to acoustic properties as they affect the performers and the performance space.

PO 310. analyzing how the basic elements of two or more arts disciplines can be used to express similar events, emotions, scenes, or ideas (e.g., sound in music, movement in dance, images in art, words in poetry).
Distinction
PO 402. transcribing music from one medium to another (e.g., one instrument to another one ensemble to another).
PO 407. analyzing and correcting one's own physical mechanics essential to playing/singing within the repertoire.
PO 408. manipulating the physical properties of voice/instrument to create a spectrum of sounds and effects (e.g., timbre/color, flutter tonguing, bending pitch, vowel change).

PO 410. analyzing how the basic elements of all arts disciplines can be used to express similar events, emotions, scenes, or ideas (e.g., sound in music, movement in dance, images in art, words in poetry)
Concept 2: Understanding music in relation to history and culture.
Beginning
PO 101. investigating the origins and development of instrumental/vocal music.
PO 102. identifying and comparing a varied repertoire of music from diverse genres and musical styles.
PO 103. playing/singing a varied repertoire of music utilizing appropriate stylistic elements reflective of history and culture.
PO 104. identifying and applying appropriate audience behavior in the context and style of music being performed.
PO 105. identifying the composers of the works being sung/ played.
PO 106. identifying various roles of music in daily experiences.
PO 107. identifying the musical characteristics that make a piece of music appropriate for a specific event or function.
Intermediate
PO 201. recognizing the origins and development of instrumental/vocal music.
PO 202. identifying and comparing a varied repertoire of music from diverse genres and musical styles.
PO 203. playing/singing a varied repertoire of music utilizing appropriate stylistic elements reflective of history and culture.
PO 204. applying appropriate audience behavior in the context and style of music being performed.
PO 205. identifying and discussing the composers of the works being sung/ played.
PO 206. identifying various roles of music in daily experiences.
PO 207. explaining and applying the musical characteristics that make a piece of music appropriate for a specific event or function.
PO 208. identifying and discussing the roles/careers musicians play in various societies.
Advanced
PO 301. describing the origins and development of instrumental/vocal music.
PO 302. identifying and comparing a varied repertoire of music from diverse genres and musical styles.
PO 303. playing/singing a varied repertoire of music utilizing appropriate stylistic elements reflective of history and culture.
PO 304. applying appropriate audience behavior in the context and style of music being performed.
PO 305. identifying and analyzing the context in which the composer wrote the work being played or sung.
PO 306. identifying various roles of music in daily experiences.
PO 307. explaining and applying the musical characteristics that make a piece of music appropriate for a specific event or function.
PO 308. identifying and discussing the roles/careers musicians play in various societies and investigate opportunities for life long participation in music.
Distinction
PO 401. applying the developmental and historical characteristics of instrumental/vocal music to performance practice.
PO 406. naming the contributions of significant composers and performers specific to the music they play/sing.
Concept 3: Understanding music in relation to self and universal themes.
Beginning
PO 101. explaining their musical preference for specific musical works and styles.
PO 102. identifying the roles and impact music plays in their lives and the lives of others.
PO 103. identify the various ways that music conveys universal themes (e.g., contrast, conflict, emotion).
PO 104. Identifying and explaining music preferences (I like it because…)
Intermediate
PO 201. describing their preference for specific musical works and styles.
PO 202. discussing the roles and impact music plays in their lives and the lives of others.
PO 203. describing the various ways that music conveys universal themes (e.g., contrast, conflict, emotion).
PO 204. Identifying, explaining, and distinguishing music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because…)
Advanced
PO 301. describing specific musical characteristics that influence their preference for specific musical works and styles.
PO 302. reflecting on the roles and impact music plays in their lives and the lives of others.
PO 303. describing the various ways that music conveys universal themes (e.g., contrast, conflict, emotion).
PO 304. Distinguish music preferences (I like it because…) from music judgments (It is good because…) from cultural judgments (It is important because…)
Distinction
PO 401. expressing personal reactions to musical experiences, and identifying which musical aspects evoke these reactions.
Strand 3: Evaluate
Concept 1: Listening to, analyzing, and describing music.
Beginning
PO 101. listening to music from various cultures and genres.
PO 102. identifying the musical characteristics that make a piece of music appropriate for a specific event.
PO 103. identifying the sounds of the instruments/voices specific to their ensemble.
PO 104. identifying instruments/\voices by family/voice type.
PO 106. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music.
PO 107. identifying the elements of music in the repertoire.
PO 109. identifying their role (e.g., melody, harmony, accompaniment, foreground/background) within the texture of the ensemble.
PO 110. identifying whether an instrument/voice is in tune by listening to a pitch reference.
PO 111. identifying the expressive qualities (e.g., dynamics, tempo, phrasing, vibrato) of music.
PO 112. listening to musical examples with sustained attention.
Intermediate
PO 201. describing music from various cultures and genres.
PO 202. identifying and describing the musical characteristics that make a piece of music appropriate for a specific event.
PO 205. comparing/contrasting the performance of a solo/ensemble in relation to the genre or style performed.
PO 206. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music.
PO 207. identifying and explaining the elements of music in the repertoire.
PO 208. comparing multiple interpretations of the same piece of music.
PO 209. describing their role (e.g., melody, harmony, accompaniment, foreground/background) within the texture of the ensemble.
PO 210. determining whether the instrument/voice is sharp, flat, or in tune by listening to a pitch reference/ensemble.
PO 211. describing the expressive qualities (e.g., dynamics, tempo, phrasing, vibrato) of music used to create different moods or feelings.
PO 212. listening to musical examples with sustained attention.
Advanced
PO 301. analyzing music from various cultures and genres.
PO 302. describing and analyzing the musical characteristics that make a piece of music appropriate for a specific event.
PO 305. comparing/contrasting the performance of a solo/ensemble in relation to the genre or style performed.
PO 306. using appropriate terminology to describe and explain music.
PO 307. identifying and explaining the elements of music in the repertoire.
PO 308. comparing and analyzing multiple interpretations of the same piece of music.
PO 309. analyzing their role (e.g., melody, harmony, accompaniment, foreground/background) within the texture of the ensemble.
PO 310. determining whether the instrument/voice is sharp, flat, or in tune by listening to a pitch reference/ensemble.
PO 311. analyzing the expressive qualities (e.g., dynamics, tempo, phrasing, vibrato) of music used to create different moods or feelings.
PO 312. listening to musical examples with sustained attention.
Distinction
Concept 2: Evaluating music and music performances.
Beginning
PO 101. identifying the characteristics that evoke a temperament or mood in a piece of music.
PO 102. using teacher specified criteria to evaluate a musical performance.
PO 103. showing respect for personal work and the work of others through appropriate critique.
PO 104. evaluating the effect of audience and performers' behavior on the performance.
PO 105 reflecting on the experience(s) of their performance and the performance of others.
Intermediate
PO 201. describing the characteristics that evoke a temperament or mood in a piece of music.
PO 202. using teacher or student specified criteria to evaluate a musical performance.
PO 203. showing respect for personal work and the work of others through appropriate critique.
PO 204. evaluating the effect of audience and performers' behavior on the performance.
PO 205. describing the experience(s) of their performance and the performance of others.
Advanced
PO 301. analyzing the characteristics that evoke a temperament or mood in a piece of music.
PO 302. using student specified criteria to evaluate a musical performance.
PO 303. showing respect for personal work and the work of others through appropriate critique.
PO 304. evaluating the effect of audience and performers' behavior on the performance.
PO 305. analyzing the experience(s) of their performance and the performance of others.
Distinction
PO 402. evaluating musical experiences orally and in writing with appropriate critique and terminology.
PO 405. Analyzing and articulating the quality of their performances and the performances of others.
